https://gist.github.com/codegangsta/7678025

BenchmarkFunctionCall 2000000000 0.57 ns/op
BenchmarkReflectCall 5000000 380 ns/op
BenchmarkInvoke 5000000 538 ns/op

Raw function call compared to a reflect call compared to an injector.Invoke call.

I'm sure you are thinking ZOMG 10X slower. But we are talking nanoseconds here. A typical Martini request will probably rack up anywhere between 5 and 15 invoke calls. If anyone considers a couple microseconds per-request too much of an overhead then you are not solving the same problems I am :)

> Hmm. Now that *log.Logger can be overridden, that does kind of change
> things. So, just to make sure I'm getting things right, here's what I think
> the problem is. Martini provides, by default, its own logging middleware
> that does some reasonable default logging for each request. The client may
> want that logging to be done to a file, or have a certain prefix, or do any
> one of a number of other things. Before, this wasn't possible. But now that
> the client can provide their own *log.Logger value, it can be done.
> 
> As you said, a *log.Logger can be created with any io.Writer, so that
> means it should work with other logging systems. For example, if you're
> logging to stdout, then:
> 
> stdLog := log.New(os.Stdout, "STD LOG: ", 0)otherLog := log4go.NewConsoleLogWriter()// inject stdLog as *log.Logger so the middleware uses it// inject otherLog which we'll use in our handlers
> 
> The problem I see with this is that you're forced to create a *log.Loggerwhich may or may not write to the destination independently of your own
> logger (from, e.g., log4go). I suppose this could be circumvented by
> providing an io.Writer that proxies everything back through the same
> logger, but that seems like a kludge.
> 
> The other approach I'm thinking of is writing a much smaller Loggerinterface. Perhaps one that only has the
> Print, Printf and Println methods. This is all that's needed from within
> Martini's current middleware. When a client asks for a martini.Logger,
> they'll get something that can only be used to print. Which I suspect is
> OK. Logger options can be set by injecting your own Logger interface
> value. If you really want access to the rest of the logger, then you can
> type assert. But this isn't the common case I think. So for example:
> 
> type myLogger {
>   log4go.ConsoleLogWriter}
> // Satisfy Logger interface
> otherLog := log4go.NewConsoleLogWriter()// inject otherLog as a martini.Logger// which will be used in Martini's middleware and can// be used in our handlers.// If the logger guarantees that writes from simultaneous// goroutines are safe, then this approach is safe.
> 
> The benefit of using an interface here is that it makes it easier for
> people to plug in other logging frameworks without having to deal with the
> fact that two loggers may be trying to write to the same destination
> simultaneously. (One and only one logger should be writing to a destination
> as it can avoid simultaneous writes, just like the standard *log.Loggerdoes.)

> I think that if we go the Logger interface route, then the user will

> logging to stdout, then:
> 
> stdLog := log.New(os.Stdout, "STD LOG: ", 0)otherLog := log4go.NewConsoleLogWriter()// inject stdLog as *log.Logger so the middleware uses it// inject otherLog which we'll use in our handlers
> 
> The problem I see with this is that you're forced to create a *log.Loggerwhich may or may not write to the destination independently of your own
> logger (from, e.g., log4go). I suppose this could be circumvented by
> providing an io.Writer that proxies everything back through the same
> logger, but that seems like a kludge.
> 
> The other approach I'm thinking of is writing a much smaller Loggerinterface. Perhaps one that only has the
> Print, Printf and Println methods. This is all that's needed from within
> Martini's current middleware. When a client asks for a martini.Logger,
> they'll get something that can only be used to print. Which I suspect is
> OK. Logger options can be set by injecting your own Logger interface
> value. If you really want access to the rest of the logger, then you can
> type assert. But this isn't the common case I think. So for example:
> 
> type myLogger {
>   log4go.ConsoleLogWriter}
> // Satisfy Logger interface
> otherLog := log4go.NewConsoleLogWriter()// inject otherLog as a martini.Logger// which will be used in Martini's middleware and can// be used in our handlers.// If the logger guarantees that writes from simultaneous// goroutines are safe, then this approach is safe.
> 
> The benefit of using an interface here is that it makes it easier for
> people to plug in other logging frameworks without having to deal with the
> fact that two loggers may be trying to write to the same destination
> simultaneously. (One and only one logger should be writing to a destination
> as it can avoid simultaneous writes, just like the standard *log.Loggerdoes.)
> 
> I think that if we go the Logger interface route, then the user will
> never actually see a _log.Logger. By default, the Logger middleware
> injects some reasonable *log.Logger *as_ a martini.Logger, which can now
> be overridden using a similar mechanism as in #224https://github.com/go-martini/martini/pull/224,
> I think.
> 
> This change would also regrettably break a lot of code, but the fix is

To add some more context to what Jeremy said: if you implement any kind of anti-CSRF protection in your application, you're looking at 2500 - 5000 ns/op to generate a random number, XOR it & convert the result to base64. That's before checking the token in the session (which will take longer still). 

You won't have CSRF on every page of course, but 538ns is a drop in the ocean (literally). In the land of web applications it'd never be the bottleneck outside of routing tiny 1KB requests.
. Just keep in mind—for those who stumble across this issue and who aren't
super knowledgable about benchmarks—that most (even large) web apps do not
spend a lot of time in the router.

I just want to make sure someone "new" to this doesn't mistake Martini's
position in those benchmarks for it being slow: very (very) few will hit a
point where the router is the hot spot.

Most of the time will be spent in the DB, writing/reading seasons and
rendering templates.

type RedisClients struct {

and then map an instance of that type instead. You can inject it in a middleware:

```go
func myCtxMiddleware(c martini.Context) {
        c.Map(context.Background())
}
```

and then get the context like this in your handlers and subsequent middlewares:
```go
func Handler(ctx context.Context) {
        // use ctx
}
```

Also, if your intention is to just keep a few values that you know beforehand you can avoid using `context.Context` and just use your custom struct directly.

```go
type AppCtx struct {
        UserID int64
        MoreStuff interface{}
}

func Middleware(c martini.Context) {

13k:
sorry to bump this, but I have a concern here regarding cleaning before termination.

martini (or any other piece of code that does not own `main.main`, for that matter) should **never** `os.Exit()` (as `log.Fatal*` does) or `panic()`.

there's no way the client code can recover from such errors and If it's allocating resources, spawning go routines, listening for other connections, connecting to remote servers, simply `defer()`ing, or whatever one ever wants to do before calling `Run*()`, then these resources might be in an inconsistent state on exit.

I think that returning the error should be the correct approach here. I see that there are other places (handler binding, I think) that use `panic()`. I think these too should bubble up an error all the way to `Run*()`, if possible.

lukescott:
I experimented with the ResponseEncoder idea and I didn't like it for the following reasons:
- There was more code added to the context run loop 
- The same code would have to exist in the router context run loop.
- The ResponseEncoder needs either the http.ResponseWriter passed as an explicit argument, or the Context needs to be. The ResponseEncoder could need other injected components.
- The focus of writing is shifted away from the middleware Handlers into a proprietary interface. This detracts from the flexible and dynamic nature of Martini. 
- What if I wanted to do more with the return arguments other than encode them?
- I did not feel it was necessary to add another interface. 

So I got to thinking. What bothered me is that Martini was making an assumption about the return arguments. So I came up with a way to give that control to the Handlers without adding more complexity. Basically Martini does nothing with the return arguments. It defers the responsibility to the Handlers, which is where it belongs. 

What I love about this approach is that a Handler can bind the request body before the Next() and encode the response after. It's clean, compact, and concise. I do not feel it to be magical at all. It's no more magical than the dependency injection. 

My plan with this is to create a Handler that I can specify on each route to specify the request body and encode the response from returned arguments. 

Admittedly Printer is probably a bad name for the default middleware. Writer would be better, but I didn't want it to be confused with ResponseWriter.

lgs:
Here it is [my preferred way](https://github.com/codegangsta/martini/issues/190#issuecomment-36508783) using [Docker](https://www.docker.io/), the LXC Container engine. When containerized with Docker, Martini can be deployed on [DigitalOcean](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/community_tags/docker) cloud hosting. . @jayrox at first you got no benefit, if you look at deploy issue from a flat simple prospective. But if your app is going to be more complex, adding multi-tier components, you're going to thanks having a lightway virtualization engine like Docker in place and your app components dockerized. Even if you have a small site and you'll fed up with your provider, Docker will help you to migrate in a blink of eye, decoupling your site from your hosting provider being that a Cloud, a VPS or bare metal as well. ... again, a bit off topic I know, but in the long term I think Martini will get a lot from LXC containerization, because of its self nature of HTTP endpoint builder and handler component, a "LEGO" attitude which is fostering distribution of self contained micro apps vs monolitic, vertical, un-manageable mega build. To see a more complete list of benefit using Docker instead of just a regular installation, just exercise your googling skills, may be starting from here: [Benefits of Docker for application deployment](http://knitatoms.net/2013/12/benefits-of-docker-for-application-deployment/) I'm not affiliated with Docker product/company, this is just IMHO. . @vaxXxa yeah, that's easy peasy. . At the end of the day, I did it myself ... Here it is my own [Dockerfile](https://github.com/lgs/docker-martini/blob/master/Dockerfile) to build & ship [containerized](http://docs.docker.io/en/latest/terms/container/) Martini (last rev.) on GOLANG 1.2 on Ubuntu 13.10 (Saucy Salamander). Feel free to use it, modify it, include it wherever you like. 
    $ docker pull lgsd/docker-martini
    $ docker run -d -p 3000:3000 -name martini -t lgsd/docker-martini:latest
    23f1c41a7e8b6bfc7b9135fd1a37a234d4536d5da876b6f50558b3385564027c
    $ docker ps -a
    CONTAINER ID        IMAGE                       COMMAND             CREATED              STATUS              PORTS                    NAMES
    23f1c41a7e8b     lgsd/docker-martini:latest   go run server.go    About a minute ago   Up About a minute   0.0.0.0:3000->3000/tcp   martini
You will now have a Martini webserver running on localhost:3000 
    $ curl localhost:3000
    Hello world!

porjo:
"Access plus 1 week" is not a valid `Expires` value. The Apache web server allows you to specify a relative expires value, but that is only for configuration. What ultimately ends up going out on the wire is an absolute timestamp of the form `Mon, Jan 2 2006 15:04:05 GMT`

The `Cache-Control` header _does_ allow a relative time to be specified on the wire. It would be good to include both headers, however it is recommended to keep `Expires` for the sake of older caching proxies.

``` bash
# Run a local Martini server.
# Run this command:
curl localhost:3000

# Now run this command:
curl localhost:3000 --header X-Real-IP:8.7.6.5
# Log output > [martini] Started GET / for 8.7.6.5
```

In the routing section:

``` go
    // instantiate Martini

    log, err := syslog.New(apilogger.Facilities[configuration.Logger.Facility], "API")
    if err != nil {
        panic(err.Error())
    }
    // map it to the logger type used by handlers
    Martini.Map(log)

    // use our own logging middleware
    Martini.Use(apilogger.Logger())
```

Then, the logger itself:

``` go
package apilogger

import (
    "fmt"
    "github.com/go-martini/martini"
    "log/syslog"
    "net/http"
    "strings"
    "time"
)

var Facilities map[string]syslog.Priority

func init() {
    Facilities = map[string]syslog.Priority{
        "LOG_KERN":     syslog.LOG_KERN,
        "LOG_USER":     syslog.LOG_USER,
        "LOG_MAIL":     syslog.LOG_MAIL,
        "LOG_DAEMON":   syslog.LOG_DAEMON,
        "LOG_AUTH":     syslog.LOG_AUTH,
        "LOG_SYSLOG":   syslog.LOG_SYSLOG,
        "LOG_LPR":      syslog.LOG_LPR,
        "LOG_NEWS":     syslog.LOG_NEWS,
        "LOG_UUCP":     syslog.LOG_UUCP,
        "LOG_CRON":     syslog.LOG_CRON,
        "LOG_AUTHPRIV": syslog.LOG_AUTHPRIV,
        "LOG_FTP":      syslog.LOG_FTP,
        "LOG_LOCAL0":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL0,
        "LOG_LOCAL1":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL1,
        "LOG_LOCAL2":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL2,
        "LOG_LOCAL3":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL3,
        "LOG_LOCAL4":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL4,
        "LOG_LOCAL5":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL5,
        "LOG_LOCAL6":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL6,
        "LOG_LOCAL7":   syslog.LOG_LOCAL7,
    }
}

// returns a middleware handler that logs requests and their response times
func Logger() martini.Handler {
    return func(res http.ResponseWriter, req *http.Request, c martini.Context, log *syslog.Writer) {
        addr := req.Header.Get("X-Real-IP")
        if addr == "" {
            addr = req.Header.Get("X-Forwarded-For")
            if addr == "" {
                addr = strings.Split(req.RemoteAddr, ":")[0]
            }
        }

        start := time.Now()
        rw := res.(martini.ResponseWriter)
        c.Next()
        log.Debug(fmt.Sprintf("%s - %s %d \"%s %s\" %s", addr, time.Now().UTC().String(), rw.Status(), req.Method, req.URL.Path, time.Since(start)))
    }
}
```

So my API only locks on a facility, after which I can just call log.Debug/Info/Warning/Err/Notice/etc.
. Replying to myself here. It seems that as long as the handler takes a martini.Params, a http.ResponseWriter and a *http.Request and returns void, the above is possible.
